title: 107_hr2715
content: The Act is titled the "Rim of the Valley Corridor Study Act." It includes findings related to the Act. The Congress finds that the greater Southern California metropolitan region, the second largest urban concentration in the US, lacks sufficient park and recreation lands per population. This deficiency will worsen with continued growth unless action is taken soon. The greater Southern California metropolitan region lacks sufficient park and recreation lands per population, which will worsen with continued growth. This deprives residents of health benefits from nature proximity and leads to increased crime and social tension. The Rim of the Valley Corridor encircling the San Fernando and La Crescenta valleys provides important scenic, environmental, recreational, educational, and scientific benefits to the California metropolitan region, addressing the lack of open space and nature proximity for residents. The Rim of the Valley Corridor surrounding the San Fernando and La Crescenta valleys offers significant scenic, environmental, recreational, educational, scientific, and economic benefits to Southern California. Increased protection is needed to ensure these assets continue to benefit the public in the future. The Rim of the Valley Corridor in Southern California offers significant environmental, recreational, and economic benefits. Increased protection is necessary to preserve these assets for future public benefit. The Rim of the Valley Corridor in Southern California, including the Santa Monica Mountains, Santa Susanna Mountains, San Gabriel Mountains, Verdugo Mountains, San Rafael Hills, and adjacent areas to the Los Padres and San Bernardino National Forests, contains the endangered Mediterranean chaparral ecosystem and unique ecotones. The escarpment of the San Gabriel Mountains within the Angeles National Forest is a key element of this corridor. The Rim of the Valley Corridor in Southern California, including the Santa Monica Mountains, Santa Susanna Mountains, San Gabriel Mountains, Verdugo Mountains, San Rafael Hills, and adjacent areas to the Los Padres and San Bernardino National Forests, contains the endangered Mediterranean chaparral ecosystem and unique ecotones. The escarpment of the San Gabriel Mountains within the Angeles National Forest is a key element of this corridor, primarily managed for watershed, recreational, and habitat values. Privately owned lands within the corridor provide additional scenic, environmental, recreational, and open space values. The forest in the Rim of the Valley Corridor is managed for watershed, recreational, and habitat values, not for commercial exploitation. Privately owned lands in the area contribute to scenic, environmental, recreational, and open space values. These lands should be protected through voluntary incentives while respecting private property rights. The State of California has adopted the Rim of the Valley Master Plan. The State of California has adopted the Rim of the Valley Master Plan to protect the unique natural and recreational resources in the area. However, efforts have been hindered by a lack of financial resources, technical assistance, and expertise that the Federal Government could provide. The Rim of the Valley Master Plan in California aims to protect natural and recreational resources, but lacks Federal Government support for financial resources and expertise. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a special resource study of the Rim of the Valley Corridor in Southern California to evaluate its national significance and the feasibility of making it a part of the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a study to evaluate the national significance of the Rim of the Valley Corridor in Southern California and its suitability for inclusion in the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area. The study will use criteria outlined in Public Law 91-383 and involve consultation with relevant stakeholders. The Secretary will use criteria from Public Law 91-383 for the study on potential inclusion in the National Park System. Consultation with the Rim of the Valley Corridor and Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area Advisory Committee is required. Establishment of Advisory Committee. The Rim of the Valley Corridor and Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area Advisory Committee is established to advise the Secretary of the Interior on a study and recommend boundaries for a new recreation area. The Committee advises on a study and recommends boundaries for a new Santa Monica Mountains and Rim of the Valley National Recreation Area, reflecting existing boundaries and including the Rim of the Valley Corridor. The Committee advises on establishing boundaries for a new Santa Monica Mountains and Rim of the Valley National Recreation Area, including the Rim of the Valley Corridor as depicted on maps filed in 2001. The Committee will submit a recommendation to the Secretary of the Interior within 365 days, including maps depicting proposed boundaries for a Santa Monica Mountains area. The Committee, consisting of 24 members, will submit a recommendation to the Secretary of the Interior within 365 days, including maps depicting proposed boundaries for a Santa Monica Mountains and Rim of the Valley National Recreation Area. Public participation in and comment on the recommendation of boundaries will be provided. The Committee, with 24 members appointed by the Secretary of the Interior, will recommend boundaries for a Santa Monica Mountains and Rim of the Valley National Recreation Area. Public participation in and comment on the boundaries will be allowed. The Secretary of the Interior will appoint 17 representatives of local governments for the Santa Monica Mountains and Rim of the Valley National Recreation Area, nominated by various city councils and boards of supervisors. The Secretary of the Interior will appoint 17 representatives from local governments in the Santa Monica Mountains and Rim of the Valley National Recreation Area, nominated by city councils and boards of supervisors including Ventura, Thousand Oaks, Agoura Hills, Westlake Village, Malibu, Calabasas, Burbank, Glendale, and La Canada-Flintridge. The city councils of Pasadena, Sierra Madre, South Pasadena, Santa Clarita, and Moorpark will also appoint representatives for the Santa Monica Mountains and Rim of the Valley National Recreation Area. The city councils of Flintridge, Pasadena, Sierra Madre, South Pasadena, Santa Clarita, and Moorpark, along with the board of supervisors of Los Angeles County, will appoint representatives for the East Rim of the Valley Trail Corridor. This decision follows consultations with the Town Council of Altadena and the Crescenta Valley Town Council. The board of supervisors of Los Angeles County will appoint representatives for the East Rim of the Valley Trail Corridor, in consultation with the Town Council of Altadena and the Crescenta Valley Town Council. The appointed representatives include the Superintendent of the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area, the Supervisor of the Angeles National Forest, and the Superintendent of the Angeles District of the State of California Department of Parks and Recreation. The stakeholders involved in the East Rim of the Valley Trail Corridor include the Superintendent of the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area, the Supervisor of the Angeles National Forest, the Superintendent of the Angeles District of the State of California Department of Parks and Recreation, the Director of the Santa Monica Mountains Conservancy, and a representative of the Rancho Simi Recreation and Park District. The Committee consists of representatives from various park districts nominated by their respective Boards of Directors. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson will be selected by the Committee. The Committee consists of representatives from different park districts nominated by their Boards of Directors. The Committee will select a chairperson and vice chairperson from its members. Members serve without compensation but will be reimbursed for necessary expenses by the Secretary of the Interior. The Committee consists of representatives from park districts nominated by their Boards of Directors. They will select a chairperson and vice chairperson. Members serve without compensation but will be reimbursed for necessary expenses. 13 members constitute a quorum for business transactions, and the Committee will terminate upon the submission of the special resources study to Congress.
